Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 27: Great Brahmā Makes a Request, and [Buddha] Travels to Varanasi.
Then the lord of the unbearable world Brahmā knew that [the Buddha rested in repose]. He thought, “The world will become unruly [if the Buddha stays like this.]”
Manual - English: Brahma offers a wheel and asks the Buddha to teach dharma. On his way to Varanasi the Buddha meets a non-Buddhist sage. When the boatman wouldn't ferry the Buddha, the Buddha flies up in the air. The above scenes are drawn as in the mainstream.

Sun of Faith - English: So he went before [the Buddha] and made a request.
Inscription - English: The god Brahmā requests [the Buddha] to turn the wheel of dharma

Sun of Faith - English: The teachings that once reigned in Magadha
were not pure; realization was tainted.
Open the door to your nectar-like teaching!
Explain [your] realization without error!
“Others will not understand what I have realized through great accumulations,” said the Buddha.
So at first he did not agree.
Again Brahmā requested, “Here in the world, there are people of great, intermediate, and inferior [capacity].
If those of great or intermediate capacity hear your teaching, they will understand it.
If they don’t hear it, they will fall lower and lower.
With wise vision the Buddha also knew this to be so.
He replied, “ I will open the door of the nectar-like [teaching].
Whoever wishes to hear it should not doubt.
Brahmā, to humans, I’ll briefly explain the excellent dharma that gives no ground for dispute.
Brahmā was pleased that the Buddha agreed, and he disappeared.
Seven weeks went by. While he was thinking of Udraka [Rāmaputra] (Rangs byed kyi bu lhag spyod) and Ārāḍa [Kālāma] (Sgyu rtsal shes kyi bu ring ‘phur), the gods beseeched him [to teach them].
[The Buddha] knew that seven days had passed since Udraka died and one day has passed since Ārāḍa died.
“Alas, things went terribly wrong for them.
If they had heard my teaching, they would have grasped its essence.
I must teach it to others.
Earlier, when I practiced austerities, the five [ascetics who were my companions] were devoted.
So I shall teach to them.”
[The Buddha] arose from the foot of the Bodhi Tree, walked slowly over the land, and travelled to Kashi.
On the path he met Ājīvika.
“Gotama, senses are sparkling.
Your complexion is so clean. Your skin radiant.
Who is your teacher?”
[The Buddha] said, “No one like me has come before; I have no teacher.
The only awakened one in the world is me.
I have attained perfect, supreme enlightenment.”
